author: diegoscalamob

description.text: Enjoy

My Bosch lawnmower stalled and melted its drive pulley - I designed and printed a replacement Update 21June 2016
It finally died - the mower ate a chunk of wood which jammed it and caused grievous harm to the pulley and tension bearing assembly. These parts have kept the old mower running for a couple of years but I now have a new one, so don't expect further updates to happen automatically. If you have specific things that you'd like to see changed I might still be able to help, please let me know in the comments. Update 4 June 2016
Lots of bad luck with this over the last week or so, I made errors with installation and assumptions about design changes to "improve" the part that did the opposite so I've gone back to interference fit on the fan with provision for tapped holes to mount the pulley but I've added a fan blade protection ring to avoid losing blades if the fan touches the casing. Just finished printing, going to test - wish me luck... Update 29 May 2016
Second failure, pulley melted, fan's fine but discovered the design is not brilliant for replacing the pulley only. Redesign should make it easier to only replace the bit that seems to fail. Photos not updated but SCAD and STLs are new. Update 11 August 2015:
I'm actually quite excited: first sign of failure! Last week, around 5 months after I made this part (!) the friction fit of the pulley on the motor shaft started to loosen and let the pulley slip a bit. It only happens on start up of the mower and it's still usable for now but is an indication of what to re-work on the next version (I'll probably go with a clamped shaft next time) I've been astonished at how long this 'temporary' repair has lasted, I'll try to redesign the part as soon as I can and I'll re-upload the new part when I've printed and fitted it. Update 1st September 2015:
The new version of the pulley is printed and working - this improves the friction fit between the pulley and the shaft and adds clamping bolts in case it's not enough.

The lawnmower is a couple of years old, no problems at all until it made a funny noise while my wife was using it, it was stopped straight away but too late - the motor shaft had slipped in the pulley and friction had melted it, belt tension pulled it off-centre and it was ruined.
I looked for a replacement part but they seem not to be available (you can buy whole motor assemblies for £130 - twice the price of a whole lawnmower).
I designed the replacement part in OpenSCAD based on measurements from the original, it's designed to print in two parts - a pulley and fan which are then bolted together.
I printed the part in PLA at 50% fill with four perimeters on the pulley, you might need to tweak the extrusion width to get a strong enough pulley.
It's bolted together using three M3 bolts. Ream the three bolt holes to 3mm on the pulley only and tap threads into the fan section after reaming to 2.5mm. You will need to ream the centre shaft hole to ~9mm - ensure that this leaves an interference fit for at least part of the shaft. If you need to tap the part onto the shaft gently using a soft-face (wooden or plastic) mallet to provide a solid friction fit but be careful not to split the plastic.

comments.text: You have two versions here now, the single piece, and the two piece attached by 3 bolts. Which one is the preferred one? How did it last, was the June 21 death which version, and how did it die?
comments.author: tkorho

comments.text: You need both parts. The pulley is printed separately from the fan and they bolt together with the three M3 bolts. The fixing so the shaft is interference so you have to tap it into place and it won't come off - tolerances on the hole need to be right for that and it will take drilling out to achieve.
comments.author: tkorho

comments.author: mb20music

comments.text:
I know, but I don't have any ABS or Nylon and I had to do something before the lawn got knee deep :)
This was a prototype really, mainly intended to check if the geometry was correct. If it doesn't die after a couple of weeks I'm going to open it up again and see how it's getting on. With the airflow it has going past it I hope it won't get too hot over most of the surface but I could easily see the teeth failing from local friction heating from the belt. To be honest even if it does only hold up for a few uses that is still around a month of use and better than buying a whole new mower; then I'd probably redesign for easy replacement of the part(s) that fail most often...

title: Modular Futuristic Tiles: Core Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: One excellent (and common) alternate use for Pocket-Tactics figures is as miniatures for RPG encounters. Because of this, I've started designing some modular map tiles fitted to their scale. Each square is 15mm x 15mm, and represents a standard "increment" of space in your game world (roughly 5 feet or 1.5 meters). This makes them perfect for D&D and similar games systems, and will work great with any 15mm scale miniature ranges. (Khurasan, Splintered Light, etc... look them up, they're fantastic!) For the full Pocket-Tactics range of models, here's the collected sets, single units and, of course, Pocket-Dungeons (which has some classically RPG-themed models): http://www.thingiverse.com/dutchmogul/collections/pocket-tactics-sets http://www.thingiverse.com/dutchmogul/collections/pocket-tactics-mercenary-units http://www.thingiverse.com/dutchmogul/collections/pocket-dungeons They print really easy and with plenty of space on a Replicator platform,so print a ton of these plates and build an epic dungeon! Check back for expansions and different tile types... plenty more to come!

title: Garmin Cup Holder Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Quick and to the Point. This is just a quick little mount that allows you to move your Garmin Nuvi off of you windshield. Personally I really  hate having my field of view blocked, and glancing down to see the map is no harder than looking somewhere else. Even better than that, my new truck has 5 cup holders in the front. Yup, thats not an exaggeration. The new Dodge 2500 Pickup has 2 in the lower console, and 3 more in the seat console. If I actually tried to drink that much, I would never make it out of town without having to stop 5 times for... well, you get the point.   
I printed both without supports and they tested very well. Depending on your printer you may need to add supports to the angled one, but it was not needed using my MakerBot Rep2. The photo shows the unit without any cleanup

Print and  use. Thats really about all you need to do.   
If, on the off chance your GPS tells you to drive off a cliff, I am not responsible if you do it. I call that a pre-existing condition. You would have been stupid long before you printed this device.  
DRIVE SAFE!!

This is a work in progress because I don't think the hinge is as big as it needs to be. I printed it and it was great except for the hinge snapped before it bent, and it didn't on the original version.   
This is a combination of two nano cases on here. One had the perfect size for the arduino inside but the hinge was too small and didn't work. The other had a great hinge but the enclosure was just a box that required pins to be cut, etc and wasn't what I wanted. I had a friend (who doesn't have an account and is fine with me taking credit) do a lot of work putting the two together and cleaning up the file.  
The little vents on the top of it are inlaid a bit, but I did not need to print out supports for them - they came out perfect!

author: aknaap

description.text: Your 3D you!

title: Mini centrifuge for 1.5ml tubes
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A small centrifuge for 1.5ml tubes. The rotor can hold up to six tubes at once. It's driven by a DC motor, a PWM module and a 9V power supply. I used the following dc motor and pwm module:
http://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B0013B6W2U
http://www.amazon.de/gp/product/B00CWSO2IY What else do you need?
  • glue for the material you use
  • 2x M3x10 screws + nuts
  • 4x M3x20 screws + 2 nuts each screw
  • 1x power switch
    (- 1x power connector)
  • 1x 9V power supply with at least 1A

After printing all parts (you need two pieces of the motor hitch, all other parts 1x) I built the centrifuge in the following order:
  • add the PWM knob and power switch to the bottom-part
  • insert the motor into the motor mount and glue it on the mid-plate (don't forget to solder the cables to the motor before you glue the motor-mount)
  • add the pwm module to the mid-plate by putting the screws from the top side through the mid plate and fix them with one nut. Put the pwm module on the screws and add another nut
  • solder the remaining wires
  • glue the mid-plate on top of bottom
  • glue the rotor-protection on the mid-plate
  • add the motor hitch by using the two M3x10 screws + nuts
  • glue the lid knob to the lid
  • if you printed rotor_bottom and rotor_top separately glue the two parts together
    • You just have to put the rotor on the hitch. It stays there cause of its own weight. As there is nothing to avoid vibrations I added four of the mounts (one at each side) and put the whole thing on a board. I never needed more than 20% of max speed and had very good results.

title: KCD4 Switch Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Nice little box to hold a KCD4 Switch (and two 7mm wire), ideal for making a remote switch for a power strip. I use it to power on/off my desk in one go, making sure i never leave the soldering iron on overnight, or during vacation. Comes with a wire clamp to neatly run wires to and from the box. You'll also need:
2x M4x20 Socket head bolts
2x M4 Nuts
1x M4x20 Wood screw Please note
  • This is made for 7mm wire.
  • You will need to cut the plastic retainer clip from the KCD4 Switch to allow 10mm of space.
  • You will need to cut the little quarter circles on one side of the KCD4 Switchs' lip (you will see it wont go in otherwise).

title: E3D Chimera/Cyclops mount for Rostock MAX

description.text: This is for mounting a Chimera/Cyclops hot end under the effector. It's compatible with my LED snap ring and other accessories, EXCEPT for the blower ducts. You will need something small, like some pliers or an Allen wrench to release the Bowden tubes. My blower duct doesn't work with these hot ends because the height is different. I have a dev version, but the exhausts are too close to the hot end so I need to redesign them a little. The fix will be in later this week. Use the three screws supplied with the hot end, and make sure your fan is hot-wired - that's it! Changelog 4-22-15: Enlarged the access holes for the Bowden feeders a little, redesigned the cable management (removed one wire clip and took the tang out of the other), and added some stiffening strakes to the top surface.

comments.text: hey man did you ever design those blower ducts? Cheers
comments.author: tr15070

comments.text: I did, but they don't work well. The heater block has a lot of surface area, so the tiniest amount of airflow will make it impossible for it to hold temperature. I had to run the fans at half speed for it to work at all, and doing so didn't improve print quality over no cooling.
comments.author: tr15070

comments.text: Are you having any success printing with PLA then? Or do you only print ABS? Did you ever try using the silicone socks E3D sell?

Bathrooms are filled with germs.  This holder stores your toothbrush in alcohol.

This thing fits a Bacon Peices bottle made by a company that rhymes with "Bormel". If you use another brand or kind, you'll have to modify the parts to fit. Also, you may wish to modify the opening to fit your specific toothbrush. Mine is slightly oblong, but the one I'm publishing is round. A snug fit will help prevent alcohol from evaporating. You'll want to cut a foam gasket for the cover. This will keep the cover snug on the bottle and also help reduce evaporation. I added foam to the bottom of my base to keep it from sliding around on the counter. No more scummy germs on your toothbrush.
Enjoy

This adapter allows you to securely attach almost any phone to almost any microscope for capturing still images or video, or for use as a digital display. After several iterations and much testing, I came upon this design. The deep eyepiece clamps allow for focus adjustment, as the optimal distance from a phone camera to a microscope eyepiece can vary. The disconnected eyepiece clamps allow for adjustment to fit a wide range of eyepiece diameters. Lastly, the sliding phone supports allow the adapter to fit a broad range of phones (pictured is a Nexus 4, though larger or smaller phones also fit). I designed the adapter myself, tested it along with my PI, and borrowed the 'knobby knob' from Thing #26752. If you have any questions or requests, feel free to ask!

• Print copies of each part:

    • Print one copy of the adapter body. The non-flipped version will fit the vast majority of phones, but a flipped version is provided just in case. If you are unsure, look at the back of your phone; if your camera is on the left, then use the non-flipped version (e.g. for all Nexus phones, Galaxy-series phones, iPhones, and most others), otherwise, use the flipped version. A file exported directly from OpenSCAD (from the rev4a SCAD file) will have some non-manifold edges, so a corrected STL is also provided (rev4b).
    • Print one copy (each) of the outer and inner clamps.
    • Print three copies of the sliding support.
    • Print five knobs, of either variety. I printed three of the round knobs, and two of the knobby knobs. Bear in mind that the knobby knobs are much easier to tighten (not necessary on the sliding supports).

  • Attach the body to the inner clamp using ABS juice (if the adapter was printed from ABS). In a pinch, epoxy or superglue may be used instead. If your print bed is large enough, you might prefer to print these as one object instead. If anyone is interested, I will upload an STL with these parts merged together.

  • Obtain (3) 1.25" #6-32 machine screws, (2) 4" #6-32 machine screws, and (10) #6-32 nuts. My local Home Depot doesn't sell #6-32 screws longer than 2.5" individually, but I did find the 4" ones as part of a set of toggle bolts which I bought for less than 1 USD.

  • Attach each knob to the corresponding screw by sliding the screw through the hole (the hole might need to be drilled out slightly, depending on the calibration of your printer), and threading the nut onto the other end. Using a pair of pliers (on the nut) and a screwdriver, tighten the screw head into the indentation in the knob (a drill might help speed up this process).

  • Drill out the holes in the eyepiece clamps and sliding supports slightly so that the screws can move freely within them. I think I used a 1/8" drill bit for this.

  • Placing each remaining nut into the corresponding nut trap, assemble the remaining parts as shown in the pictures.

  • If desired, add Sugru (moldable silicone) to the insides of the eyepiece clamps and sliding supports for better grip.

  • Take some beautiful pictures!
    • Tip: if the edges of your images are fuzzy, try loosening the adapter and moving it up and down until they are focused to a hard edge. Tighten.

The "Westinghouse Petite Crackle Solar Path Light, Black" is both very cheap and quite pretty. Here is a mount you can print to stick them on fenceposts or other flat surfaces.

Why use these lights on fenceposts instead of other lights?  Well, I've been using other solar lights for years, but most only extend about 15mm inside their mount and I've had problems with them getting blown out of their mounts -- especially for lights with shapes that can catch wind. The head of this light has a very pretty and unusual design in which both the solar cell and white LED are inside a fairly heavy glass ball and the battery is inside the shaft, extending about 45mm in. Thus, these lights are far less likely to be lifted out by wind. I suspect the glass ball also is better protection against the weather than the plastic covers most solar lights use, although there is a bottom drain hole which I'd recommend partially blocking so bugs can't get in.  
Some of the solar lights I've tried on my fenceposts were pretty expensive, and some even came with mounting plates. These lights are quite cheap; I bought mine at Walmart for $1.50 each. They come with a 170mm hollow mounting post and ground spike -- neither of which is used in my mounting design. Instead, you simply 3D print the custom mount, nail or screw it to the top of the fencepost, and drop the light head's shaft containing the battery into the 3D-printed mount.  
The mount prints in about half an hour on my MakerGear M2 using 0.25mm PLA with 5% fill. It's plenty solid despite using only about 11g of PLA.

title: OpenSCAD Alternate Mendel X Axis Motor Bracket

description.text: When I tried to print the original version that rhys-jones made, Skeinforge choked on the very high element count in that model. Turns out all of the rounds and holes are meshed really fine. So all I did here was recreate it in OpenSCAD. This had the benefit of reducing the polygon count for the holes (sort of as described by nophead here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6118) I tried to make the scad file the same geometry as the previous version, but OpenSCAD doesn't like me to make tangent cuts for the big rounded cutout, so I removed the rounds and left it square. Shouldn't change the assembly at all.

print out, clean the holes as necessary, and install. Full instructions here (not mine):
http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel_Alternate_X_Motor_Bracket

title: Wall holder for Stanley Low Angle Block Plane (G12-060)

description.text: I like having my tools neatly mounted on my workshop wall, so I designed this wall mount holder for my Stanley Low Angle Block Plane (G12-060). It's angled at 15 degrees so the plane sits nicely and stays in place without a magnet or anything. The holder has two screw holes and I used two Kreg 3/4" pocket hole screws to fasten it to the plywood wall. I should mention that I have no relationship with Stanley besides buying their tools, so if this object transforms into a monster lizard and eats your neighbors it's your own fault for buying nuclear printer filament.

I printed this in PLA with a 0.2mm layer height and 15% infill, no supports are necessary. This model fits really perfectly with that combination, so if you print with ABS or another material that shrinks at all you might need to scale it up slightly.

description.text: The mount it ships with Foscam wireless IP cameras is too short requiring you to rotate the base which limits the field of rotation or you can mount your camera base at an angle which works but isn't optimal for all situations.  I've created a replacement piece for the back half of the mount.  There are two versions.  The first has a slightly less than 90 degree angle and is designed for spring pressure.  This is made to pressure fit to standard corner molding as shown in the picture.  This lets me adjust the height at will which is nice when using it for meetings etc.  The other has mounting holes.  With the camera mounted right on a corner this design allows me to get maximum area coverage from my camera.

title: Kyosho Mini-Z Ferrari 360GTC Front Body Mount

description.text: Another broken front body holder, this time of an older and harder to find replacement - Ferrari 360GTC body for Mini-Z, so we have designed a replacement one that we can 3D print ourselves. So here comes a replacement 3D printable front body mount for the Ferrari 360GTC body for Kyosho Mini-Z RC models that you can print and use if your stock front body mount breaks like in our case and you cannot find an original replacement. The body holder should be a perfect fit and provide enough strength and durability, just like the original one. We recommend to use 0.1mm layer height for best results and the use of support structure as some part of the body mount is in the air and it will not be useable if don't use supports. This was designed using inventor, but Sketchup is also suitable. I just used inventor to learn about the stress tests

Objectives Learn about design, robotics, electronics. Audiences Depending on the progression, this project can apply to any variety of audiences. From toddlers using the finished product, to engineers at the start of the design, to teenagers in the assembly and programming of the servos Preparation The project has several steps and stages, each part requires basic skills related with the used tools and materials: 1) Design part requires a 3d modeler software and a 3d printer
2) Assembly part
3) Hardware testing and programming (electronic)
4) Software control Results Since the project could be very long, each step has several results concluding with a working robotic puppet

author: markosgr

title: Medium Filament Spool (Ideal for Flashforge Dreamer)

description.text: A simple, attractive, midsize filament reel, ideal for spooling loose filament or readying a select amount of humidity-sensitive filament for printing.

Modeled in Cinema4D, with minor cleanup in netfabb Basic, I wanted to strip away most of the unnecessary structure that my earlier small spool had. This one is shockingly lightweight, uses very little filament, and feels durable for its weight. I also think it's quite beautiful.  
Print the "bottom" piece and select which "top" you want. One of the top pieces has the FlashForge logo in it (since I have a FlashForge Dreamer that I love), the other is plain.  
My earlier, smaller design was unnecessarily fidgety to assemble. This one should work easily with ABS adhesive (I use Loctite Plastics Bonder) - and should even work just fine with clear quick-set Gorilla Glue because of the tight overlap. Apply the adhesive to the parts where they overlap.

comments.author: steamindustries

comments.text: Yeah, I used "FlashPrint" a couple of times right after I got the printer and it was "ok" - it has Flashforge's own slicer and has support for a couple other opensource slicers: you can get great results out of the opensource ones if you know what knobs to fiddle with. I tried out Simplify3D and I've had such great luck with it that it's really all I use at the moment. If I'm using a new exotic material (like Laywoo-D3 or Ninjaflex, vs. "normal" PLA or ABS) I'll spend some time doing test prints and adjusting settings so that I can save a profile specific for that material. That helps a lot.

author: calesella

title: Rubber-Band Escapement Test Jig - Maker Block Edition

description.text:
Maker Block asked if there was a way to have fewer, larger teeth on the escapement wheel, and thanks to the power of parametric design in OpenSCAD, the answer was a resounding yes!
With the larger teeth, this should be much easier to print.
(EDIT: added a beefier, thicker version, slightly smaller so the pendulum fits inside the build platform. Duncha love parametric designs?)

As with the original:
Print out the drum, the pendulum and the support.
Attach the support to a vertical surface, and slip the drum and pendulum onto their respective pegs (see jpeg for what goes where).
Attach one end of a rubber band to the side of the drum, wind it around the drum a couple times (nothing too tight, just a little potential energy for the machine) and attach the other end to the remaining peg.
Push everything as far back as it will go against the stops, making the pendulum's escapement pallets mesh with the drum's teeth, and let go. Give the pendulum a gentle nudge to get it going.
Write an angry comment here telling me it didn't work! ;-)

title: Axminster Band Saw Guard Plate (no Holes)

description.text: FRESH START MONDAY. This is a Guard Plate for an axminster Band Saw. A Friend of mine broke his from his shed, so I've drawn this up for the 20th April 2015 Design a Day reboot. What went wrong? It Broke. What went wrong with my "Design a Day"? I lost mojo. This has a 45deg chamfer on one side to allow th bedplate to tilt and cut at different angles. I would recommend this is CNC cut, not 3D Printed. If you MUST 3D print, please acetone paint before use. This is the basis for Tuesday's "Design a Day" - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:780908 It has the extra holes the original had.

author: bathrobotics

title: Axminster Band Saw Guard Plate (now with Holes)

description.text: This is a Guard Plate for an axminster Band Saw. Similar to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:780900 but now with added holes. These were on the original, but probably weaken any additive / subtractive manufactured parts. Why are they there? Air flow? Sometimes You remove material from IM parts to avoid weakening the parts (often there are cavities inside the part where the material has shrunk away from the centre towards the walls). This has a 45deg chamfer on one side to allow th bedplate to tilt and cut at different angles. I would recommend this is CNC cut, not 3D Printed. If you MUST 3D print, please acetone paint before use.

title: Spring clip tensioner and vibration dampener for Rostock Max

description.text: Vibration dampener and slack tensioner for rostock max arms.

I cad'ed this out in Alibre and put it into an STL. I used a 1/8"x3/8" dowel pin and then 3 - 6.5x22mm springs that pull together with loops. I manually drilled out the dowel pin holes with a standard 1/8" drill bit but there is enough material for you to use whatever you want to secure the springs. This file doesn't have any holes and can be customized as you like.  
I printed these with full infill and they clip on and hold great to the rostock max platform arms.

comments.text: Just a heads up. I printed these and found they do not fit on the rostock max v2. The v2 has larger arms.

comments.text:
I did not use any insulation - air is a great insulator and the inside always have flowing air, keeping the plastic "cold"
But I did have a few drops dripping off of the plastic that the duct was printed from. But then it stopped dripping, I like to say that it auto-calibrated :)
This fan is a total hack, it just looks nice.
The reason that it does not fit the standard mount is that I used a custom mount. The 15mm sounds about right for the standoffs. I never expected this to get the attention that it got and I don't use the diamond anymore, so I never cared to change it.

title: Vison 3D Printer Filament Cooling Fan Duct Revised

description.text:
This idea is a remix of the http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:63123 to fit a Vision 3D Printer.
It was remodeled and it fits a 40mm fan. Since I now have a 3D model that I can modify I may make new versions to fit a 50mm and a 60mm fan if neeed to cool the extruded plastic quicker.
I added a new fan duct that I think is a better more efficient design.

I printed mine with supports.
.3mm layer height, .50 nozzle, 3mm ABS filament.
The two vertical holes fit onto the "X" Carriage bearing block screws, just add two nuts to hold it. By threading in two 3mm screws into the two horizontal holes you can adjust the angle of the forks or to support a larger, heavier fan. I printed mine with supports.
I printed the new duct without supports.
.4mm layer height, .50 nozzle, 3mm ABS filament.
The two vertical holes fit onto the "X" Carriage bearing block screws, just add two nuts to hold it.

https://grabcad.com/library/skull-1
uploaded to Grabcad 3 years ago by
Babanatsas Theoharis
https://grabcad.com/babanatsas.theoharis.teo I have printed no less than 350 of these skulls over the last 3 or 4 weeks mostly at 20mm Z height size in rafts of 24(qty) (9 hours/24raft)! The one photo shows all my 50mm (2hr20min/each) ones and an 82mm and some 102mm skulls (14hours/each). It's a great test part and really puts my Printrbot through it's paces, plus I learn something about the skull every now and again! I didn't know what to do with the rafts of 20mm skulls, so I broke them down and stuck them in a gumball machine! Cura: 0% fill, shell 1.2mm, top/bottom 1.2mm, 45-60mm/sec, support type: line set to 20% (jaw and upper molars are the biggest print issues)
I started using Teo's model when Nicole downloaded it as an indexer test for my ShopBot. Since then, I've made half a dozen or so out of Cedar and now I'm trying to make one 50mm skull out of every color of PLA filament I can get my hands on.
Thanks and all attributions to Teo. I love this model!

Bei meinen German RepRap Neo muss der Bowden exakt gerade abgeschnitten werden. Einfach den Bowden in den Bowden Cutter stecken und mit einem Cuttermesser abschneiden. Achtung, Vorsichtig und ohne Druck schneiden damit der Bowden nicht verrutscht. Danach das Abfallstücken mit einem dünnen Stab oder Zahnstocher von der Rückseite aus entfernen.
English:
The bowden of my German RepRap Neo must be exactly cut straight . Simply put the bowden in the bowden cutter and cut with a cutter knife . Attention, cut without pressure so the bowden does not slip Then remove the waste pieces with a thin stick or toothpick from the back side.

author: somersjeroen

description.text:
I was adding ailerons to my GWS Slow Stick and needed a control horn. There are some here on thingiverse but they are all one-piece and have weakness at the layer interfaces.   
I've designed this control horn to be printed in two pieces so that the layers of each piece are printed in an orientation that makes the part as strong as possible.  
Print the parts, they are meant to fit together. For PLA, epoxy the two parts together. I printed mine in ABS on an Afinia H-Series printer. I quickly dowsed my horns with acetone and left them to dry outside. The acetone acts as a glue and also binds the layers together.  
I made the base pad kind of large since I was planning on gluing it to my aileron. There is enough material there to drill some mounting holes.

comments.text: Why wouldn't you print it as a single piece?
comments.author: amagalla

comments.text: I designed this in 2 pieces so that it entire assembly would be stronger. If it was printed all in one piece, the layer orientation would create a weak vertical piece (the part with the holes). If the control horn broke in-flight, the plane would no be controllable.
comments.author: amagalla

title: JD Humanoid built with EZ-Bits that clip together

description.text: JD is a 3D printable biped humanoid that clips together with EZ-Bits. You can change the appearance and build of this robot by connecting the parts differently to build any configuration. Here's a video of it working: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z0vbSMv28Oo

The instructions involve photos, which you can find here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Tutorials/Lesson/61?courseId=1 Here is how the parts clip together: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aA0oXMz0QPg There larger servos used in this robot's arms and legs are here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?productNumber=7 The smaller micro servos used in the head, neck and grippers are here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?productNumber=13 The camera for the head is here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?productNumber=1351 The RGB eyes are here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?productNumber=1358 The MicroController Brain is here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?productNumber=40 The LiPo battery is here: http://www.ez-robot.com/Shop/AccessoriesDetails.aspx?productNumber=41 The iOS and Android App can be downloaded here: https://www.ez-robot.com/Community/EZCloud/RobotApps.aspx Windows software for programming EDI can be found here: https://www.ez-robot.com/EZ-Builder/windows

description.text:
Are you tired of buying expensive toys for your bathtub, pool, or collection of things that float. We have you covered here at Makersome. With this easy print item you will be getting nautical in no time. Never worry about losing the Torpedo to the deep because another copy is just a push of the button away. Instructions:
  • Download the STL file for the Torpedo
  • Pop it into your slicer of choice
  • We recommend using PLA with extruder setting of 200°C or ABS at 230°C. A layer height of .2 (or medium resolution) and 20% infill so it floats.
  • If you do not have a Glass Bed we recommend not to use a heated bed, but if you do have the Glass Bed Upgrade Kit then we recommend using a bed temp of 70°C
  • Use rafting and supports while printing this project
  • Load your project onto an SD card or connect your computer to your printer (just use your preferred method here)
    Congratulations, you’re ready to print!
    • For more 3D printing projects check out.. Our 3D printing projects page at:
    http://makersome.com/3d-printing-projects/ Our YouTube channel at:
    https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCv00IAervOUnsipGhwTC9rA/feed And remember to Like, Comment, and Share if you like what you see.

remixed_from.author: racatack
remixed_from.title: Z Axis Endstop Adjuster for Rigidbot

description.text: I was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:362662 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:417410 to upgrade my z limit switch for better bed leveling control. I couldnt get the other two projects to line up with the switch correctly, so I made a new one that works for me. To install you just slide it over the two cylindrical protrusions from the bearing holder on the X-axis gantry. Then insert two 3mm x 5mm screws to lock it in place. I used a 3mm x 16mm screw for the vertical adjustment. You can then spin the z access switch around 180 degrees from it's original position and start fine tuning your bed level. I put a second hole in it in case you want to reverse the switch position.
I sliced it with Simply3d 30% fill to make sure it was solid.

description.text: Warning!, not printed yet, the inner part will certainly not fit/slide because I did not adjust it, and was planning to sand it until fit theen adapt model later. This a remix from 3 great design and ideas I found around. The main one is here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/k40-chinese-lasercutter-air-assist-with-cross-lines-laser. I just love the design and the laser pointer idea, and I adapted it to integrate two other great ideas: 1)from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:445354 (combining two lines laser pointer to have a cross working on all heights) and 2) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CC9kGOlxlHs (adjusting focus, ihooooo, thanks bro!)

Part 1 is the main hed extension (replacing the original lens holder. Do not know how good/bad is the fit yet. Part 2 is the inner slider that will let you adjust the lens height. A thirs part can be found here: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/k40-chinese-lasercutter-air-assist-with-cross-lines-laser . I wanted you to have a look at his page to see how it works and to give him the credits. I was not planning to use it but I might be wrong! About the BOM, I bought these cheap lasers here, I guess they are ok because I'm always optimistic, but to be honest, I did not even check the size :-) http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-Red-5mW-650nm-Line-Laser-Module-Focus-Adjustable-Laser-Head-5V-Industrial-Grad/32290741097.html

author: george5017

title: Lumbar Vertebrae and Sacrum, in easy printable format

description.text:
These are models of the individual lumbar vertebrae (L1-L5) and the sacrum, based on the 3D models available in the bodyparts3d database. I cut the models in half to facilitate printing, just make sure the flat side is down in the prep, then print the two side and glue them together. Comes out quite nicely, the original models are very well done. In the pictures, I have the L1 vertebrae and the complete L1-Sacrum. These models are full (life) size. Although the models don't look it in the thingiverse preview, they are closed. The BodyParts3D uses a creative commons/share-alike license.
http://lifesciencedb.jp/bp3d/?lng=en. Credit to Cbonsig for pointing out this excellent database and putting up another nice version of the lumbar spine.

comments.text: Very nice! Love that they seem anatomically accurate and are to scale, but are clean models. Most others on thingiverse are not individual vertebrae, or are not anatomically accurate. Personally would have preferred the models unsliced. Are you going to do the thoratic vertebrae anytime per chance? That would be awesome to have the full vertebrae set!

title: Fitbit Flex Paracord Bracelet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The rubber bracelet that comes with the Fitbit Flex keeps ripping in half - I have gone through 3 so far.  
This removes the need to keep buying replacements, plus the paracord bracelet is cooler than the rubber bracelet!  
At some point I may put a window so that I can see the status lights, but it is thin enough that you can see the lights through the print.

After printing the two pieces, make your paracord, but somewhere in the middle, run the two cords (not the bracelet core) through the side tunnels, then continue on the other side.  
Then put the Fitbit Flex in the center channel, and snap the second piece over to hold it all together.  
I did this with a 4 cord core using the Cobra braid, with the center core running outside the bracelet on the bottom (i.e. next to the wrist).  
Another option would be to run two of the center cores on the top and bottom - this makes the holder more centered, but it also makes it thicker, and harder to remove the Flex for charging.

description.text:
This Rocket is designed to carry the payload of an egg and calculate it's own max height. Fits a C-class engine. Uses an ADXL 345 accelerometer ran by an arduino pro mini and a 3.7V RC car battery to measure it's own height. Accelerometer records steadily in Z axis only because it sits inside the gimbal. Sand paper on tip is to reduce the drag coefficient (see related photo). http://youtu.be/KzeIY8nQlFs Launch Video:
http://youtu.be/qeUkx9SPBbU Rocket was designed by Eric Smith (The Man, The Myth) and Dan Sluder (The Science Tutor)

The code provided is mostly stock code from arduino with minor changes. Once the data is harvested you can use the .m code to numerically integrate the data and get the height. Set up is self explanitory. To make the parachute we followed this video:
www.youtube.com/watch?v=nnZbji8Payc Works much better without an egg. I recommend tossing "Gimbal Chamber to Egg Chamber Union" and flying it like that.

Beehive legs that block ants from getting into the hive.

You'll probably need to print 4 of these (one for each corner of the beehive stand). If you print them solid (100% fill), the legs should come out very strong so that they can support the weight of a full beehive BUT be sure to test them before using them on the hive. If you decide to permanently attach the legs, each one will just need a screw and washer to fasten it through the center hole and into the wood of the beehive. After leveling your hive, you can add water, oil or some other substance into the moat of the leg. That'll block ants and other crawling insects from marching up into the hive. The legs will need to be checked periodically to make sure something isn't laying across the moat or that the ants haven't sacrificed themselves as bridges for the colony. Update (April 23rd, 2015) - I've added a rain cap that goes over the leg to keep rain from washing away the oil or other things you put in the moat. The small circle cutout can be rotated into position for viewing or filling the moat and then rotated again to hide it. Update (March 7th, 2016) - I've added a second rain cap. This one is removable. I found that it was too hard to clean bugs and dirt out with the original rain cap. I'm also trying water this time. I'll have to replace it more often but it shouldn't get things as gummed up as with the canola oil.

comments.text: If I'm not mistaken, that's a Warré hive, right? I have 2 that I built myself - it's so nice to see another Warré enthusiast!
comments.author: ACinSV

comments.text: Yes, it's a Warré. The moat works well but you just have to keep it filled with water or a vegitable oil. Oil lasts longer (because of evaporation) but is messier.

title: Tesla Model S Wall Charger Plug Holder

description.text:
This is a plug holder you can screw into the wall to hold your Tesla Model S charging plug when it's not in use.  
Inside the OpenSCAD file is a vector profile of the charging cable itself that could be re-used for other projects :)

I would suggest printing this in ABS, I've found that HIPS was too hard and would make nicks on the Tesla connector after a while.  
In the pictures I only printed it with two screw holes because that's all I had at the moment. I would suggest using all 4 screw holes to get a solid fit.

author: mamodom

description.text:
This is a custom made small base for Fantasy Flight Miniature compatible games (ex: X-Wing Miniatures, or Star Trek Attack Wing). The base is intended to be a compatible replacement for the originals. It should accept standard pegs, as well as the custom peg I've also included here. Changes:
  • 6/14/15
    • Added a recreated long peg, compatible with the FF models. Has improved grip in the small base, easier to print.
  • 5/18/15
    • I recreated the base from scratch in Inventor, since Fusion 360 was getting pretty limited for me.
    • Front notches no longer extend to the edge, allowing the template to be placed on either side. This is to help maneuvering with ships in close proximity to each other.
    • Deeper center hole for original peg. (Fits very well, now)
    • Improved grip on squadron markers.

description.text: Larxene's knives from chain of memories.
Use supports

Eww ...  
Now you can have lice of your very own!  
I had thought of making my model of a louse with the clear PLA, pausing the print, and then color in a little red magic marker in the abdomen and restarting it. Does anyone know if this will mess up my printer?  
Anyways, i made this with White PLA on a replicator2 on the high setting. Tried to make this as small as i could while still being able to save the antennas.  
Can anyone make this smaller?  ...this is a louse after all.

I've included a blender file and a .stl file at the size that I printed
You will need supports.
  • Print
  • Print some more
  • More still...
  • Smear with mayonaise and let sit for a few hours
  • Wash EVERYTHING on the HOT setting
  • Repeat
    (don't actually do steps 4-6)

comments.text: I just printed one of these out of glow in the dark ABS, came out great.  I used Simplify3D and added extra support under all legs and antennae as a precaution and I was amazed at how well the support came away from the fine details.

comments.text: Nice model! I actually have a lot of respect for these things. They are getting immune to the shampoo that is supposed to kill them. si es muy chico, multiplicar su tamaño por 1000.
if is too small, multiply x100 size.

This is a Turner's Cube which is basically a sphere inside of a cube. The CAD is mostly my friends idea with the final adjustments made by me to optimize the printability. The STL should print with only a raft layer to keep the sphere in place then cut away after printing.   
This is my first upload so I decided to upload the solidworks file as well if anyone wants to make changes. The cube is 1"x1"x1".  
If I had a dual nozzle printer I would make the inner sphere a different color for contrast.
